question: What landform is most likely to form when an oceanic plate subducts beneath a continental plate?

content.source_1: At an oceanâ€“continent convergent boundary, fluids released from the subducting oceanic slab promote melting in the overlying mantle wedge; the resulting magma commonly rises through the continental crust to build a continental volcanic arc (for example, the Andes or the Cascades).
content.source_2: Repeated intrusion and eruption of this magma along the overriding plate produce stratovolcanoes and a linear volcanic mountain range parallel to the trench.
content.source_3: Where the subducting oceanic plate is unusually buoyant (such as young, warm lithosphere or an attached oceanic plateau/ridge), the slab can flatten beneath the continent, cooling and displacing the mantle wedge so that arc magmatism is strongly reduced or shuts off for hundreds of kilometers.
content.source_4: In such flat-slab segments, compression is transmitted far inland, generating a broad, non-volcanic fold-and-thrust mountain belt and regional uplift (e.g., the Laramide orogeny in North America and volcanic gaps in parts of the central Andes).
content.source_5: All subduction zones are characterized by a deep ocean trench at the plate boundary and commonly an accretionary prism, regardless of whether a volcanic arc is active or suppressed.
content.source_6: Oblique convergence can partition deformation onto strike-slip faults along the margin, while the presence or absence of an active volcanic arc is controlled primarily by slab geometry and thermal structure rather than by convergence alone.
